Body:
I am not sure whether that answer your question, but English and French also have the "partitive" meaning some indeterminate quantity of something.

French: du pain, de la salade, de l'argent, des Ã©pinards

English: bread, some bread ...

It shares its written form with the singular or plural, but is really neither.

LastEditedUser.AboutMe:
Travelling armchair linguist.

Never studied in an institution but read books and web with probably more breadth than depth.

Always on the road surviving in a strange foreign language, currently Mongolian and Mandarin Chinese.

And I collect dictionaries.

OwnerUser.AboutMe:
The name Babou was given to me by my grandson (two years old at the time). It actually means grandpa in Armenian and Swahili.
